<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_read:
```c
int metal_io_block_read(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       void *restrict dst, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	unsigned char *dest = dst;
	int retlen;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_read) {
		retlen = (*io->ops.block_read)(
			io, offset, dst, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
		while ( len && (
			((uintptr_t)dest % sizeof(int)) ||
			((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)))) {
			*(unsigned char *)dest =
				*(const unsigned char *)ptr;
			dest++;
			ptr++;
			len--;
		}
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); dest += sizeof(int),
					ptr += sizeof(int),
					len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)dest = *(const unsigned int *)ptr;
		for (; len != 0; dest++, ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)dest =
				*(const unsigned char *)ptr;
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation:
All other controlling expressions depend on runtime-varying values and therefore are not invariant and need not be investigated for Rule 14.3:

- if (!ptr) — ptr is returned from metal_io_virt at runtime; condition depends on runtime pointer value.
- if ((offset + len) > io->size) — depends on offset, len and io->size (runtime values); not invariant.
- if (io->ops.block_read) — checks a function pointer in a struct; runtime-determined.
- for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); dest += sizeof(int), ptr += sizeof(int), len -= sizeof(int)) — the condition depends on len which is modified in the loop; not invariant.
- for (; len != 0; dest++, ptr++, len--) — the condition depends on len which is decremented; not invariant.

The only fragment worth investigating is the first while loop with the alignment checks. That controlling expression can collapse to an invariant constant on some platforms: if sizeof(int) == 1 then ((uintptr_t)dest % sizeof(int)) and ((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)) are always 0, making the whole condition effectively (len && 0) which is always false (a compile-time invariant). This would violate Rule 14.3 (exceptions do not permit an always-false while). Therefore that loop is reported for investigation.
